title: Fair settings for deaf people.
body:
I am wondering if there is an option for deaf people that would indicate that eg.: Sion has used his Ultimate ability, because if there is not I think there should be, maybe in a form of some kind of screen border.

If anyone does not agree with me, and thinks this would bring huge advantage to non-deaf players too, the setting may cause that when you are turning on this option on in-game sounds would disappear, since deaf people cannot hear anyway.

Please share your opinion and upvote.

Why did you even start this comment? The dude was asking for a way for deaf players to know when sion ults, then you comment something completley irilevent, then start complaining when people don't take your comment seriously.

Well he does have a point and it's better for someone to clarify the meaning of a word so it does not get used in the wrong context. They may have gone about it the wrong way, but saying a particular industry is racist to deaf people is incorrect.  In addition, if someone wrote "racist to deaf people" on a poster to make people aware of an issue, he or she will not be taken seriously. Anyways, people might get offended if they did say deaf is a race, when it clearly is not.

In regards to the music industry, at this moment I do not think that there would be a way for them to help the deaf with listening to music. The music industry can write captions but if someone was deaf from birth, then they would still be unaware of what instruments sound like. So having a caption saying "Guitar playing" may not help the deaf person at all. However, there have been some instances where the deaf are able to make music themselves based on the vibrations they feel coming from the instrument they are playing. 

If anything, I feel like we should be asking if there is a way to bring back hearing to deaf people. If the medical industry can "cure" blindness to a certain extent, perhaps they are currently working on ways to allow the deaf to hear again?

I think this would be very nice for the deaf community. We have color blind options (although not for all kinds of colorblindness it is still somewhat helpful!), and we have options to increase the volume if you are hard of hearing (or changing the amounts of each volume) so why not have a border indicator for those that cannot hear the game? Or those that cannot play with volume settings? (I for one rarely use sound because it interferes with either the music I'm playing OR is too loud for my family and my headset is missing). I don't think this would create an unfair advantage. I do, however, think it should be a very short indicator so that it can't be used just because you weren't listening for the sound and needed a second indicator. Maybe a short yellow flash around the border of your screen (as a warning color instead of red for damage). With the colorblind option still used for it (in case both deaf and colorblind?).

Being profoundly deaf myself - although I wear implants and can hear relatively well with them - I believe that this change is an important one to make, and that Riot should consider it.

Sound effects are among the strongest cues in League - they warn you about an incoming enemy ability, when a turret was switched focus to you, and even tell you whether or not you actually last hit that cannon minion (since we all know they're so important).  Being deaf basically takes away half of the gameplay, since  sound effects not only are indicators, but also include regular game sound, like the announcer, background music, and champion lines (yes, I listen to those).  As a result, giving deaf players visual options to make up for the sound effects they cannot hear - at the very least, the sound effects that impact gameplay - is a step Riot definitely should take.

About 1 in 20 people (I'm no expert on statistics, but I believe this is about right) have some form of hearing loss, ranging from mild to profoundly deaf, and tens of millions of people - possibly hundreds of millions now - play League (in 2014, 27 million people were reporting playing _per day_, and that was 3 years ago).  So, it stands to reason that there are at least a significant number of deaf players in League, and therefore Riot should create visual options to replace the sound effects they cannot hear.  As Kerkoc said, disabling the sound when the visual indicators are activated is a fair tradeoff, so the combination of the two doesn't become an unfair advantage to hearing players.

This is a gameplay update I personally believe Riot should implement, and I hope that someday they will implement it.  After all, they have color-blind options, so surely the next step is to cater to the deaf player base, and improve their League experience.

We have colourblind mode I don't see a reason why we shouldn't get a mode for deaf people or at least make it so that global sounds are more transparent.

As an industry, video gaming is pretty behind relative to most other media in its provisions for customers with disabilities, or lack thereof. This could be a good opportunity for Riot to become a leader in the field and develop better standards and practices for providing alternative gameplay options for players with disabilities, including deaf players. Global quotes are intended to act as a warning, and thereby have gameplay purposes, so it would help to have some kind of screen tint, icon, subtitle, or other visual cue to indicate them, if only as an option. Similarly, having some sort of cue for an impact sound on abilities (i.e. when your spell hits something out of sight, but gives a sound cue indicating that it hit something) would also help deaf players, or even just players who don't have the in-game sound on too much. Many hearing players put on music or play in loud environments, so having these visual aids would benefit everyone, not only deaf players. Seeing how League has one of the largest playerbases out of any video game in the world, it's for certain that there are thousands of players with disabilities who play League. If there is a way to convey the full experience to them as well, they deserve to have it.

Global quotes are intended to act as a warning, and thereby have gameplay purposes, so it would help to have some kind of screen tint, icon, subtitle, or other visual cue to indicate them, if only as an option." 

I am not deaf or anything, but yes to all this. 

>"Similarly, having some sort of cue for an impact sound on abilities (i.e. when your spell hits something out of sight, but gives a sound cue indicating that it hit something) would also help deaf players..."

Now we get into tricky territory. This sort of specific information could be easily exploited and would take more resources to apply to every ability. Furthermore in the case of piercing abilities (Yasuo tornado) designing a visual cue to say "you hit something" could turn into "you hit something **here**" or make you **think** that's what i means. This could affect clarity when paired up with other aspects of the game. 

>"...or even just players who don't have the in-game sound on too much. Many hearing players put on music or play in loud environments, so having these visual aids would benefit everyone, not only deaf players. "

Okay, let me first say I don't dislike the idea. I do, but it has a big problem. Specifically tacking into account that league in it's core is a competitive game having visual aids for sound cues could be exploited. Those who are deaf would have a better experience because they'd be able to perform better but those who aren't deaf would also perform better with the added info. 

The option would be to simply make it a toggle as many others have mentioned here. You can either hear the sounds or see them. Sadly there are those who are not 100% deaf and can hear somewhat. I would dare to say those would enjoy to hear what they can from their games especially with the unique VOs some skins get and such; harder to appreciate but it's still enjoyable. Having to compromise to have a better edge could feel bad.

All this said I guess the option would be to be able to submit something to validate how deaf you are and be given access to enable the visual sound queues. Given how Riot adds new settings and toggles to preferences (like the arcade "accent" in SR) it would be easy to hide/show it per account. 

>"Seeing how League has one of the largest playerbases out of any video game in the world, it's for certain that there are thousands of players with disabilities who play League. If there is a way to convey the full experience to them as well, they deserve to have it.

Agreed, despite my bitter sweet relationship with League I can't deny how huge it is. I am sure this could have popped in someone mind at Riot and this is a good reminder as well. The question is when they could make a team to tackle this small but delicate project. 

*Now to get back to my studies >.< Wish me luck.*

Best of luck with your studies, and thank you very much for the reply!

I agree with the core concern here: if done wrong, visual cues like these could easily end up giving more information than the audio cues, which would be unfair in a competitive game. Riot already made this mistake accidentally with certain skins, such as with Zombie Brand, whose change in animation could be used to detect invisible units. This is why I think it would be important to design cues that specifically _don't_ convey more information than they should, and why it would help to design a methodology for this. In the end, however, I still think this is completely feasible: in the case of an impact cue, for example, having some sort of non-directional screen tint or flash, or something similar on the ability icon or champion itself, could potentially convey impact, even multiple impacts, without revealing any more information than would the equivalent sound cue.

Ultimately, while the competitive integrity of League is something that needs to be preserved, I do not think that really goes against providing services to players with disabilities. Colorblind support is widely accepted, for example, and isn't seen as an unfair competitive advantage. Even without going into the nitty-gritty of impact cues, global quotes and whatnot, something as simple as subtitles for champion soundbites (or just quotes added directly to the chat feed, visible only to them) could already provide an immense improvement to the enjoyment of deaf players, who currently have no real way of experiencing a champion's in-game personality outside of their look.
